Post_Title: Faith is useless when it comes to finding out truth
post_text:
Hey everyone, I’m not very big on complicated arguments, so I’ll keep it very simple: You can believe literally anything on faith. People believe all kinds of religions on faith. You can believe in any kind of supernatural claim, any kind of racist, sexist ideology purely on faith. Anything you can think of really. 

If you can believe anything on faith, it is a useless tool when it comes to finding out any kind of truth, and people who care about believing as many true things and as few false things as possible should discard it.

Edit: I really should have defined faith first. My bad. I define faith as belief without evidence.

Faith does not mean believe in something without evidence. I've seen atheists making this mistake often.

Research the word "pistis" in the context of the New Testament. "Pistis" or faith is used as confidence or trust in something based on evidence. When i say i have faith that the bank won't steal my money i don't say i have blind faith. I have confidence that the bank is unlikely to do something like that. My confidence is based on evidence, prior experience, the experience of other peopl etc. Then i make a probability: it's really unlikely that the bank will steal my salary. I have faith in the bank.

Faith *can* be in things without evidence. But it also *can* be in things with evidence. Like any tool it can be used reasonably or unreasonably. So I can have faith that my dad will pick me up after school based on evidence that he will, and if the evidence is good the result is reliable. Or I can have faith that my dad will pick me up after school with no evidence that he intends to, and I may end up stranded.  In both cases I had faith. Only the reasonable faith was useful as far as being reasonably reliable to truly accomplish my goal. Even if random and unreasonable faith, pure guesses, might by chance also end up being eventually shown true sometimes, faith is only reliably useful, as a tool to accomplish something, when it is based on evidence.

> Hebrews 11:1 Now faith is the assurance of things hoped for, the conviction of things not seen.

While at first glance that one verse taken out of context could seem to be promoting faith without evidence, the examples of this faith given in the chapter include people whom God spoke to. God apparently audibly evidenced himself (or itself) reliably enough for them to have faith. So even the figures held up in Hebrews 11 as examples of faith didn’t *necessarily* have a faith with no evidence, even if technically “blind” with regards to visible things. Even if they had no objective visible evidence to show someone else, if they had audible or other evidence they still had evidence through which they came to know God. And so they had faith based on *evidence* and based on *reason.*

> Hey everyone,

Hola

> If you can believe anything on faith

You can hit anything with a hammer. You can break glass, dent metal, or chip concrete.

> , it is a useless tool when it comes to finding out any kind of truth,

Therefore hammers are useless when it comes to building anything. /s

> and people who care about believing as many true things and as few false things as possible should discard it.

That is false.

People who care about believing true things which they have technically incomplete evidence for (but evidence which nonetheless makes their conclusion likely to be true in their opinion according to their best judgment) should use faith. People who have no evidence to support any sort of likelihood their conclusion is true should not use faith.

Similarly, people who care about building structures with wood and nails should use hammers. People who care about installing glass should not use hammers.

Faith can be useless when placed in things without evidence. But it also can be placed in things with evidence and so be useful. Like any tool it can be used reasonably or unreasonably. So I can have faith that my dad will pick me up after school based on evidence that he will, and if the evidence is good the result is truly reliable. Or I can have faith that my dad will pick me up after school with no evidence that he intends to, and I may end up stranded. In both cases I had faith. Only the reasonable faith was useful.
